mission: Our research centres on the gap between the formal adoption of Freedom of Information legislation and its real-world implementation. Using a rigorous field experiment methodology, we send standardised FOI requests to public administrations under controlled conditions, varying the requester profile while keeping the requested information constant. This allows us to measure what actually drives administrative responsiveness — or silence.

We combine experimental approaches with computational text analysis — topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and multinomial logistic regression — on large-scale datasets from Belgium’s national FOI platform, Transparencia.be. The result is one of the most comprehensive empirical pictures of FOI implementation in Europe.

highlights.title: Field Experiments
highlights.text: Controlled experimental protocols across entire national systems — testing every municipality in Belgium, with expansions to Switzerland, Romania, and South Africa.

highlights.title: Citizen Science
highlights.text: Graduate students and civil society organisations participate as co-researchers, building civic capacity while generating robust empirical data on transparency.

highlights.title: Computational Analysis
highlights.text: NLP pipelines processing thousands of FOI requests — LDA topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and multinomial logistic regression on 10 years of platform data.

highlights.title: International Comparison
highlights.text: Replicating our methodology across different legal frameworks and administrative cultures to build comparative evidence on FOI implementation worldwide.

legal: Belgium’s commitment to transparency is enshrined in Article 32 of the Constitution, which guarantees every person the right to consult any administrative document and to obtain a copy, except in cases and conditions stipulated by law. This constitutional provision forms the bedrock of all FOI legislation in the country.

The federal FOI law was adopted in 1994 (Loi relative à la publicité de l’administration / Wet openbaarheid van bestuur), establishing a formal framework for citizens to request access to administrative documents. Each region and community has subsequently adopted its own complementary legislation, creating a layered system of transparency obligations across the country.

Belgium’s federal structure adds considerable complexity to FOI implementation. The country comprises 3 communities (French, Flemish, and German-speaking), 3 regions (Wallonia, Flanders, and Brussels-Capital), 10 provinces, and 581 municipalities. Each level of government operates under its own FOI regime, with varying degrees of compliance, resources, and institutional culture. The general statutory deadline for responding to an FOI request is 30 days, although extensions are possible in specific circumstances.
